text: We used deletion analysis and transfection assays with reporter gene constructs to examine the transcription control elements in the 5 ' flanking region of the human <extra_id_0> EpoR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

In erythroid cells most of the transcription activity was contained in a 150 bp promoter fragment with binding sites for transcription factors AP2 , <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the erythroid - specific <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The 150 bp <extra_id_0> hEpoR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter exhibited high and low activity in erythroid OCIM1 and K562 cells , respectively , reflecting the high and low levels of constitutive <extra_id_0> hEpoR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression .

The <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding sites in this promoter lacking a TATA sequence were necessary for a high level of transcription activation .

Protein - DNA binding studies suggested that <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and two other CCGCCC binding proteins from erythroid and non-erythroid cells could bind to the <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding motif .

By increasing <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> levels via co-transfection , we were able to transactivate the <extra_id_0> hEpoR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter in K562 cells and non-erythroid cells , but not in the highly active OCIM1 cells , although <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels were comparable in OCIM1 and K562 .
